review.title: A Cognitive Architecture for the Implementation of Emotions in Computing Systems
review.abstract: In this paper we present a new neurobiologically-inspired affective cognitive architecture: NEUCOGAR (NEUromodulating COGnitive ARchitecture). The objective of NEUCOGAR is the identification of a mapping from the influence of serotonin, dopamine and noradrenaline to the computing processes based on Von Neuman's architecture, in order to implement affective phenomena which can operate on the Turing's machine model. As basis of the modeling we use and extend the L\"ovheim Cube of Emotion with parameters of the Von Neumann architecture. Validation is conducted via simulation on a computing system of dopamine neuromodulation and its effects on the Cortex. In the experimental phase of the project, the increase of computing power and storage redistribution due to emotion stimulus modulated by the dopamine system, confirmed the soundness of the model.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: In recent years, the complexity and power of the human brain / mind system has been further revealed by several studies, and a myriad of questions relating to mechanisms and functions have still not been answered. An increasing number of biologically inspired studies and publications have been read in the scientific community, ranging from approaches to Artificial Intelligence (AI) to outcomes of general interest in information technology (IT). It has been widely acknowledged that emotions play an important role in human life Picard (1997); Arbib and Fellous (2004); Marsella and Gratch (2003). However, traditional AI approaches do not take into account all dynamics and creative aspects of the mind and therefore call for new attacks on the problem of mind modeling. There are several projects worth mentioning in the context of emotions and affection simulation in cognitive architectures: Kansei implements an emotionally oriented approach Nagamachi (2010), Emotions are considered in CogAff and Chrisley Simulatics.

sections.heading: 2. The problem
sections.text: It has historically been believed that AI systems can be built on traditional computer architectures for specific purposes, and that with enough computing power and memory resources, plus some good algorithms, a human-like symbolic intelligence was feasible. It was only a matter of time, money and technology after the initial excitement in this regard (mainly in the 50s of the last century) and numerous failures in achieving the desired results, it has lately been hypothesized that this may not be the case. sections.heading: 3.1. From real emotions to artificial ones
sections.text: The idea behind the assignment of neuromodulators to system parameters is to create a link between the Von Neumann architecture (abstractly a Turing Machine) and the neuroendocrine system. Our research makes it possible to implement a biologically inspired architecture based on neuromodulators. As we will show in the next sections, this innovative approach can open up new avenues in the automatic control and development of computer systems, and our goal is to take radically different paths.

sections.heading: 4. Validation
sections.text: To validate our approach, we have implemented dopamine neuromodulation of the fear response in the computer system and are reviewing an axis of our model. In this section, we report on preliminary experiments we have conducted. Specifically, in section 4.1, we describe the setup of the experiment, while in section 4.2, we present the results obtained.

sections.heading: 4.1. Experiment description
sections.text: The experiment looks for the validation of dopamine neuromodulation and its influence on a cerebral cortex and thus on thought processes. We generally assumed that thought processes operate analogously to, or could be expressed as such, computer processes. We implemented a nigrostriatal dopamine pathway published by Albin et al. sections.heading: 4.2. Results
sections.text: In our simulation with the spiking tool NEST for neural networks, we wanted to show these mechanisms, with particular emphasis on the neuromodulation of dopamine. In particular, we observed during the experiments the spiking activities of the thalamus and the motor cerebrum, which responded to this nerve modulation. We therefore created a spiking network model of the entire nigrostriatal signaling pathway, which simulated its behavior in the simulation timeframe of 0.1000 ms. At 400 ms, we triggered a volume transmission of dopamine in substancia nigra and observed the effects in both the thalamus and the motor cerebrum. Figure 3 describes the reaction of the thalamus. It shows the increasing spiking activities immediately after the input of substancia nigra, highlighting a growing activity on computing power and increasing its utilization. As a side effect, this reinforced the synapses among neurons, thereby increasing the persistence of the data.
